content.webTitle: Retailers begin to push up prices

fields.headline: Retailers begin to push up prices
fields.bodyText: The Bank of England received an inflation warning yesterday when the Confederation of British Industry revealed that surging consumer demand allowed retailers to push up prices for the first time in nearly two years, writes Heather Stewart. The CBI said shops were exploiting the pickup in activity to widen depressed profit margins. Fears that inflation would undershoot its 2.5% target have led the Bank's monetary policy committee to cut rates three times this year, but it is expected to leave them at 5.25% at their monthly meeting today. Higher year-on-year sales were reported by 56% of retailers in May, with grocers and shoe shops seeing some of the biggest rises in demand, according to the CBI's survey. Only 21% said sales were lower. Service sector firms also saw a turn-around last month, as they shrugged off the impact of foot and mouth. A survey for the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply showed growth in new business for hotel and catering firms. The sector as a whole showed stronger growth than in April.
